channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Russia Unleashes New Strikes as Ukraine Plans Cabinet Shake-Up
item.description: Several ministers offered to resign in a major reshuffle of Ukraine’s government. While rescuers searched the rubble of a deadly strike on a military academy in eastern Ukraine, another Russian attack killed seven in the west.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: Poltava Strike Aftermath Drains Ukraine’s Seasoned Rescuers
item.description: Repeated air-raid alerts have punctuated the search through the rubble in Poltava, in eastern Ukraine, after an attack that killed more than 50 people.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Russian attack that hit the military academy in Poltava, Ukraine, also shattered windows in a nearby apartment block.

item.title: Cease-Fire Talks Present Tough Choices for Gazans Devastated by War
item.description: Some say they will reluctantly stomach a postwar Israeli military presence in the territory if that allows them to go home. Others worry about another long-term occupation.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair, Hiba Yazbek and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:credit: Mohammed Salem/Reuters
item.media:description: Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, in August. Amid cease-fire efforts, Gazans said in interviews that they were mainly concerned about getting home safely after multiple displacements and bombardments.

item.title: The Pope’s Visit to Indonesia, in Pictures
item.description: Starting in the majority-Muslim nation, Francis is undertaking a multiday journey through Asia and Oceania.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Tiziana Fabi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The pope arriving in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Damning Final Report Into Deadly Grenfell Fire Is Released
item.description: A damning final report into Britain’s worst residential fire since World War II blamed a litany of cost-cutting, dishonest sales practices and lax regulation for the blaze that killed 72 people.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grenfell Tower, as seen from a nearby Underground station, in London, in 2017.

item.title: Russia Strikes Ukraine, Killing 7 in Lviv, Local Authorities Report
item.description: Russia attacked a number of cities a day after a devastating strike in the country’s east, Ukrainian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: Roman Baluk/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers and emergency workers carrying an injured person at the site of an attack in Lviv on Wednesday.

item.title: Mexico’s Lower House of Congress Approves President’s Judicial Overhaul
item.description: The vote was the first step toward shifting the country to a system in which nearly every judge would be elected to office. The bill now moves to the Senate.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judicial workers on strike in front of the Federal Judicial Branch building last month over President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s proposed overhaul of the country’s judicial system.

item.title: Hounded From a Beauty Pageant in South Africa, Then Crowned in Nigeria.
item.description: A South African beauty pageant contestant with Nigerian heritage was forced to withdraw from the competition after her participation fueled anti-immigrant sentiments.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Nelson C.J.
item.media:credit: Benson Ibeabuchi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Chidimma Adetshina after being crowned Miss Universe Nigeria 2024 at the pageant in Lagos, Nigeria, on Saturday.

item.title: Pope Praises Indonesia’s ‘Delicate Balance’ Within Diversity
item.description: Speaking in Jakarta, the pontiff said “mutual respect” was the key to harmony in the majority-Muslim country, where a pluralist tradition has been put to the test by extremist groups.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Willy Kurniawan
item.media:description: Pope Francis, center, and President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, left, at the presidential palace in Jakarta on Wednesday.

item.title: Two Years After Deadly Floods Hit Pakistan, It’s Happening Again
item.description: Millions of people still recovering from the devastation of 2022 are bracing for the possibility of losing what they’ve rebuilt.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Insiya Syed
item.media:credit: Insiya Syed for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flooding in Sehwan, in southeast Pakistan. Unusually heavy rains are lashing the country during this year’s monsoon season.

item.title: Maduro Declares Christmas in October in Venezuela
item.description: With the nation’s democracy in shambles, President Nicolás Maduro tries to inject some holiday cheer.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Hirsaid Gomez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The government, without providing evidence, accused the opposition of causing a nationwide blackout on Friday.

item.title: At Least 12 Die Trying to Cross English Channel, French Officials Say
item.description: Over 60 people were crowded into a small boat that “rapidly and brutally” broke apart off the coast of France, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Gareth Fuller/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A group of people thought to be migrants are being brought in to Dover, England, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ugandan Opposition Leader Bobi Wine Shot in Leg in Clash With Police
item.description: Mr. Wine, a pop star turned politician who ran for president, is in the hospital, but his injuries are not life-threatening, one of his lawyers said.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Abubaker Lubowa/Reuters
item.media:description: The Ugandan opposition leader Bobi Wine lies in bed at St. Francis Hospital in the capital, Kampala, after he was injured when police fired at his convoy.

item.title: Russian Missiles Hit Poltava, Ukraine, Killing More Than 50
item.description: More than 50 people were killed by two high-speed missiles that hit a military academy in the eastern city of Poltava, one of the most lethal Russian strikes in the war.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder, Yurii Shyvala, Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers clearing debris from a destroyed floor of a military academy on Tuesday in Poltava, Ukraine, after Russia struck the area with two ballistic missiles.

item.title: With New Taliban Manifesto, Afghan Women Fear the Worst
item.description: Three years into its rule, the movement has codified its harsh Islamic decrees into law that now includes a ban on women’s voices in public.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghanistan is the most restrictive country in the world for women, according to some experts.

item.title: U.S. to Accuse Russia of Using Its State Media to Influence 2024 Election
item.description: American spy agencies have assessed that the Kremlin favors former President Donald J. Trump, seeing him as skeptical of U.S. support for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Glenn Thrush and Steven Lee Myers
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman/Getty Images
item.media:description: An RT broadcast in Moscow in 2019. The United States has said that Russian intelligence agencies have been using the state-owned broadcaster to spread disinformation.

item.title: Ukraine Foreign Minister, Dmytro Kuleba, Offers His Resignation, Official Says
item.description: Dmytro Kuleba has lobbied Kyiv’s allies to supply missile defense systems. He was among several Ukrainian ministers who offered to resign on Wednesday, an official said.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Kenzo Tribouillard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dmytro Kuleba, Ukraine’s foreign minister, at a NATO meeting in Brussels in April.

item.title: With Hopes Frayed in Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, Mediators Plan a New Push
item.description: The latest proposals to bridge the remaining gaps between Israel and Hamas have yet to be finalized. Both Israel and Hamas have expressed pessimism over the prospects for an agreement.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators blocking a road in Tel Aviv on Monday during a rally calling for a deal that would release hostages held in Gaza.

item.title: Netflix Adds Disclaimer to Indian Show After Anger Over Hijacker Names
item.description: The series, based on a 1999 plane hijacking, prompted backlash on social media. Critics claimed it wrongly portrayed the Islamist hijackers as Hindus.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Suhasini Raj

item.title: Climate Change Is Making Glacier Tourism More Popular, and Riskier
item.description: More tourists are eager to visit vanishing glaciers and ice caves, but warming is also making the sites unstable.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:credit: Vilhelm Gunnarsson/STOD2, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescue teams at the scene of an ice cave collapse on the Breidamerkurjokull glacier in Iceland last week.

item.title: 6 European Cities Where You Can Swim in the Wild
item.description: Looking to take a dip in or near a city center? Here are some urban areas that have successfully opened up waterways for swimmers.
item.dc:creator: Julia Webster Ayuso
item.media:credit: Andreas Meichsner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A swimmer leaping into the water at Kalvebod Bolge, in Copenhagen.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Casualties from a Russian strike in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Missiles struck a military academy in Poltava, Ukraine.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Starlink Agrees to Block the X Social Network in Brazil
item.description: Brazilian regulators had said Sunday that Starlink planned to defy government orders to block X in the country. On Tuesday, the satellite-internet service said it would comply.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Eraldo Peres/Associated Press
item.media:description: A screen in a shopping mall in Brasília showing an image of Elon Musk on Monday. The text reads, “Musk creates profile against Moraes on X to leak confidential decisions of the Supreme Court.”

item.title: Timeline: Ukraine-Russia War’s Deadliest Attacks
item.description: At least 11,520 civilians had been killed in the war, according to a United Nations report in July, which said the true tally may be higher.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A residential building in Dnipro, Ukraine, that was hit by a missile in January of last year.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Russian Strike Kills 50 in Ukraine
item.description: Plus, a quiz to test healthy brain habits.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction at a military educational institution in Poltava, Ukraine.

item.title: Lebanon Detains Riad Salameh, Former Head of Central Bank
item.description: Riad Salameh, once seen as an international financial wizard, is the subject of multiple inquiries and has attracted blame for the country’s economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Mohamed Azakir/Reuters
item.media:description: Riad Salameh at Lebanon’s central bank in 2023.

item.title: The Olympian Rebecca Cheptegei Is Set on Fire in Gasoline Attack
item.description: Rebecca Cheptegei, a long-distance runner who competed in the Olympic marathon in Paris, is in critical condition after a man poured gas on her and set her on fire, police in Kenya said.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Jimmy Gitaka
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Rebecca Cheptegei competed at the Discovery 10-kilometer race in Kapchorwa, Uganda, last year. She suffered severe burns on Sunday in an attack by a man who set her on fire in Kenya, officials said.

item.title: U.S. and Iraqi Commandos Targeted ISIS in Sprawling Operation
item.description: The number of insurgent attacks has increased, officials say, as Iraq and the United States negotiate a plan to wind down the U.S.-led military mission.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Thaier Al-Sudani/Reuters
item.media:description: Iraqi Special Forces during an operation against ISIS fighters in the desert of Anbar, Iraq, in 2022.

item.title: Witnesses Describe Horrific Scene in Poltava After Russian Missile Strike
item.description: The devastation of the strikes on Tuesday was shocking even to Ukrainians who have seen many such scenes during the war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Liubov Sholudko and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters resting on Tuesday with their rescue dog after trying to find people in the rubble at the Ukrainian military’s Institute of Communications in the city of Poltava.

item.title: Head of Ukrenergo Electric Company Ousted as Russia Pounds Power Grid
item.description: The head of Ukrenergo was reportedly blamed for failing to fortify energy infrastructure, which has come under steady Russian bombardment, leading to blackouts.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Sergei Supinsky/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People wait for a bus in Kyiv during a partial electricity blackout following Russian strikes on Ukrainian energy infrastructure in August.

item.title: South Korean Teenagers Detained Over Deepfake Sexual Images
item.description: The country has been hit by a wave of sexually explicit videos and pictures that have spread online, prompting the authorities to launch a sweeping investigation.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Anthony Wallace/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Activists wearing masks, hold posters reading, “Repeated deepfake sex crimes, the state is an accomplice, too,” during a protest in Seoul last week.

item.title: Russia’s Attack on Poltava Comes After a Week of Strikes in Ukraine
item.description: Moscow appears to have stepped up the tempo of its attacks, resulting in a wave of death and destruction in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A municipal worker on Saturday after two missiles struck overnight in Pokrovsk, Ukraine.

item.title: 129 Dead in Congo Prison Jailbreak
item.description: Inmates at the overcrowded Makala prison had sought to escape their suffocating cells after water and power went out. At least 129 were killed, some two dozen of them shot dead, the government said.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Sanjana Varghese and Malachy Browne
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A still image from a video shows police officers outside the Makala prison in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, on Monday.

item.title: John Podesta, Biden’s Top Climate Negotiator, to Visit China
item.description: John Podesta is expected to push for China to set more ambitious greenhouse gas targets.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Michael Reynolds/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: John Podesta, President Biden’s chief climate diplomat, at the White House in 2023.

item.title: Putin Gets a Red-Carpet Welcome in Mongolia Despite Arrest Warrant
item.description: Ukrainian officials expressed outrage over the Russian leader’s visit, warning they would seek to “ensure that this has consequences” for Mongolia.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Vyacheslav Prokofyev/Sputnik, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia with President Ukhnaa Khurelsukh of Mongolia, in Ulaanbaatar on Tuesday, in a photograph released by Russian state media.

item.title: Dozens of Hostages Are Still in Gaza: What We Know
item.description: More than 60 living hostages, and the bodies of about 35 others taken captive on Oct. 7, are still in Gaza, the Israeli authorities say.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters showing some of the hostages seized on Oct. 7, in Tel Aviv in November.

item.title: As Israelis Push for Hostage Deal, Netanyahu Refuses to Change Course
item.description: In strikes and protests, many Israelis are pushing their government to prioritize the release of hostages above the immediate defeat of Hamas. But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has refused to change course.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators blocked a road in Tel Aviv on Monday, calling for a deal for the release of hostages held in Gaza.

item.title: Pope Lands in Indonesia, Where Muslim-Christian Harmony Is Under Strain
item.description: Indonesia is proud of its religious diversity and its reputation for tolerance, but minorities, including Catholics, still face discrimination.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Three percent of Indonesia’s 280 million people are Catholics. Some worshiped at Jakarta Cathedral, in the capital, last week.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Protests and work stoppages in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Tel Aviv yesterday.

item.title: A U.K. Succession Drama: Who Will Replace U.S. Ambassador Karen Pierce?
item.description: Diplomat Karen Pierce has built alliances with Trump officials and the Biden-Harris administration. But with her term set to end next year, the U.K. government has a dilemma over her replacement.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Britain’s ambassador to Washington, Karen Pierce, whose term is scheduled to end in early 2025.

item.title: An Incomplete List of Everything Threatening China’s National Security
item.description: Watch out for Good Samaritans with ulterior motives, packages in your mail and college students looking to make a quick buck, China tells its people.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:credit: Roman Pilipey/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Chinese government has made national security the country’s top priority.

item.title: Two U.S. Marines Attacked in Turkey by Nationalist Youth Group
item.description: Turkish officials said they had detained 15 members of the group. The two servicemen had returned to the ship and were safe, U.S. officials said.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stelios Misinas/Reuters
item.media:description: Two U.S. Marines stationed aboard the U.S.S. Wasp were attacked by members of an anti-American youth organization in Turkey on Monday.

item.title: Eden Yerushalmi, an Israeli Hostage Killed in Gaza, Is Seen in Hamas Video
item.description: Ms. Yerushalmi, 24, was one of six captives whose bodies the Israeli military recovered from Gaza over the weekend. It was not clear when the video was taken.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Shir Torem/Reuters
item.media:description: Mourners at the funeral for Eden Yerushalmi, one of six Israeli hostages found dead in Gaza, in Petach Tikva, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Netanyahu Stands Firm on Cease-Fire Terms Amid Growing Outrage in Israel
item.description: In his first news conference since the bodies of six killed hostages were recovered, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu refused to budge on his conditions for any truce in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The protests in Tel Aviv on Sunday night were the largest of the war, an outpouring of grief over the death of six hostages, whose bodies were recovered this weekend.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Growing outrage in Israel
item.description: Plus, Europe’s overwhelmed destinations.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Tel Aviv yesterday.

item.title: Virginia Ogilvy, Confidante to Queen Elizabeth II, Dies at 91
item.description: Born into New York wealth and married to a Scottish earl, she was the only American-born lady-in-waiting to the queen, serving for nearly 50 years.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Cathay Pacific Cancels Flights to Inspect 48 Airbus Aircraft After Engine Issue
item.description: An Airbus A350 jet experienced a problem during a flight that was supposed to travel from Hong Kong to Zurich. The airline has canceled 24 return flights.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Tim Chong/Reuters
item.media:description: A Cathay Pacific Airways Airbus A350 like this one experienced an “engine component failure” and returned to Hong Kong.

item.title: Thousands Gather in Israel for Funeral of Hersh Goldberg-Polin
item.description: It was reminder of the perilous situation facing dozens of remaining hostages still thought to be alive in the war-ravaged Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of Hersh Goldberg-Polin, one of six hostages whose bodies were retrieved from Gaza, in Jerusalem on Monday

item.title: U.S. Seized an Airplane Owned by Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro
item.description: The Biden administration said the airplane had been illegally exported for Mr. Maduro. U.S. officials accuse him of undermining the results of a presidential election he lost.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Cristobal Herrera-Ulashkevich/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A Dassault Falcon 900EX owned and operated by President Nicolás Maduro, among others, at Fort Lauderdale Executive Airport in Florida on Monday.

item.title: Order to Block Elon Musk’s X in Brazil Is Upheld
item.description: Mr. Musk has criticized the blackout of the social network in Brazil as a campaign by a single, crusading justice. On Monday, four other justices affirmed the ruling.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Ueslei Marcelino/Reuters
item.media:description: Judge Alexandre de Moraes at the Brazilian Supreme Court. On Friday, he issued an order to block Elon Musk’s social network X.

item.title: Putin Begins Meetings in Mongolia in Defiance of I.C.C. Arrest Warrant
item.description: The Russian president is making a state visit to a country that is heavily dependent on Moscow for oil.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and David Pierson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Byambasuren Byamba-Ochir/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia, right, with President Ukhnaa Khurelsukh of Mongolia, at an official welcoming ceremony in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, on Tuesday.

item.title: UK Suspends Some Arms Sales to Israel
item.description: Britain’s foreign secretary, David Lammy, said there was a “clear risk” some weapons might be used to commit “a serious violation of international humanitarian law.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli jet fighter flying above Sderot, Israel, in October.

item.title: Biden Says Netanyahu Is Not Doing Enough to Free Israeli Hostages
item.description: President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel are at odds once again as negotiations over a cease-fire and hostage release deal drag on.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking to the press as he returned to the White House from Rehoboth Beach, Del., on Monday.

item.title: Gao Zhen, Artist Who Critiqued the Cultural Revolution, Is Detained in China
item.description: Mr. Gao is being held on suspicion of slandering China’s heroes and martyrs, an offense punishable by up to three years in prison, his brother said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gao Zhen, left, and Gao Qiang, with their artwork, “Mao’s Guilt,” in 2009.

item.title: Histadrut, the Labor Union Behind Israel’s Strike, Has Long History of Influence
item.description: The union, which predates Israel’s founding, led a strike last year that helped force Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to suspend a plan to overhaul the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Gili Yaari/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Arnon Bar-David, leader of Israel’s largest labor union, Histadrut, speaking at a protest outside the Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: Pope Francis Begins Grueling Asia Tour
item.description: The 11-day trip, a signal that Francis does not intend to slow down, requires nearly 45 hours of air travel and meetings in tropical climates.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Riccardo Antimiani/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Pope Francis last week in St. Peter’s Square, Vatican City. His 11-day trip to Southeast Asia signals he has no intention of reducing his outreach to faraway Catholics.

item.title: Hamas Documents Reveal Tunnel Battle Strategy
item.description: Hamas leaders spent years developing an underground warfare plan. Records from the battlefield show the group’s preparations, including blast doors to protect against Israeli bombs and soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier walking out of a tunnel in the Gaza Strip during an escorted tour by the military for international journalists in December.

item.title: The Quiet Collaboration Between Paralympic Athletes and Their Assistants
item.description: For competition partners who share the mutual goal of winning medals, eye contact or a simple touch can be all the communication that’s needed.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerusa Geber dos Santos of Brazil, right, with her guide, Gabriel Garcia, winning a 100-meter heat in Paris on Monday.

item.title: The Four Mysterious Guardians of the Artist Lee Bul
item.description: This fall the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s facade will feature strange, humanoid sculptures. If they induce a feeling of nausea, that’s what Lee was going for.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Russeth
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The South Korean artist Lee Bul at a studio in Goyang City, outside Seoul, with her works in progress for the facade of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan.

item.title: In a Kyiv Classroom, Cries for Help From Children Scarred by War
item.description: “They are like a bleeding wound, and no one sees it,” a schoolteacher said of her pupils, many of whom have fled frontline areas or lost family members in the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Listening to a lesson by the teacher Iryna Kovaliova at a school in Kyiv, Ukraine, in March.
